author: timbeiko
content:
Re: Berlin fork blocks, what do people think about having a staged deployment for testnets? 

When all clients are synced to YOLOv3, we choose a fork block for Testnet 1 ~3 weeks out, Testnet 2 ~4 weeks out, Testnet 3 ~5 weeks out, and mainnet 7-8 weeks out. This way, if Berlin breaks one testnet, we can ship an update that disables it before it goes live on all the other networks. We can also choose the order based on usage so that testnets with the highest traffic get forked first and have the most time pre-mainnet. 

Having this also means we can choose the mainnet block early, and only need people to update once if nothing goes wrong. 

I'd propose going Goerli -> Ropsten -> Rinkeby, but it's not a strong preference. Re: Kovan, OE can do whatever they feel is best üëç

author: timbeiko
content: One implication of this for Berlin + London, if we want to ship it this summer, is that we'll need to work on London before Berlin hits mainnet. This shouldn't be a huge issue, and I've laid out what a tentative timeline could look like here: https://github.com/ethereum/pm/issues/245. Added to next ACD for discussion.

author: ryanleeschneider
content: Should we wait until testnet 1 is successfully forked before choosing the mainnet block?  That way we have more confidence that the mainnet fork will happen and will be less likely to "retract" the mainnet block which might lead to confusion.  Basically release N has the testnet blocks defined, release N+1 includes the mainnet fork block but is released sometime between testnet 1 and testnet 3 forking (where N is different for each client obviously).

author: timbeiko
content: I'm agnostic to that: I think there's a security tradeoff on both ends: either we risk having people think they've already updated but their release doesn't have the mainnet block (i.e. they don't read farther than "Berlin" on the announcement), either we risk having to issue an "emergency release" which disables/pushes back/etc. the block.

author: timbeiko
content: I think in both cases, "sophisticated" users will probably be fine (ex: Infura/Etherscan/Exchanges/etc. will know they haven't updated mainnet, but will also know if something goes wrong on the testnets)
